body:
I'm happy to tackle this one if we can get some more context based input on list item 3 above. Personally I vibe with keeping it as `Timer::just_finished` since that already clearly states what is happening and prepending `is` muddies the message a bit IMO. `Timer::is_just_finished` doesn't roll off the tongue or add context the same as the change from `Timer::finished` to `Timer::is_finished` does. 

We also have prior artwork here for utilizing `just` as it's own category predicate in input events where we have `just_pressed`

> 3\. I note there is `Timer::just_finished`. I honestly don't know about that one. I think `Timer::is_just_finished` probably works and follows the rule, but I could also see `Timer::just_finished` continuing to make sense with `just_` being its own category of predicate naming similar to names like `has_` or `must_`.

Since it's querying the state of the timer, just as the others are, I believe it should be renamed to include the `is_` prefix too. This not only ensures consistency, but makes it easier to find once the user finds `is_finished`.

That said, I'll admit `is_just_finished` doesn't quite sound right. Perhaps `is_finished_this_frame`?

> Since it's querying the state of the timer, just as the others are, I believe it should be renamed to include the `is_` prefix too. This not only ensures consistency, but makes it easier to find once the user finds `is_finished`.

My only counter point is that bevy currently runs all gamepad/keyboard input through `is_pressed` and `just_pressed` so I feel like we have prior artwork that all new users will see very quickly when they're working through their first few examples while learning, so I don't think discoverability will be an issue. Plus the docs.rs page and any modern IDE / lsp shows all your methods, and for a struct with < 25 methods I wouldn't be too worried that it's hard to discover.

I feel like `just_finished` is concise, descriptive and my preference, but if we change it here we should probably also go change it in the input code as well.

issue.title: Rename Timer::finished and Timer::paused to is_finished and is_paused

labels.name: D-Trivial
labels.description: Nice and easy! A great choice to get started with Bevy

labels.name: C-Code-Quality
labels.description: A section of code that is hard to understand or change

labels.name: C-Usability
labels.description: A targeted quality-of-life change that makes Bevy easier to use

labels.name: S-Ready-For-Final-Review
labels.description: This PR has been approved by the community. It's ready for a maintainer to consider merging it

labels.name: M-Migration-Guide
labels.description: A breaking change to Bevy's public API that needs to be noted in a migration guide

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective
Renames `Timer::finished` and `Timer::paused` to `Timer::is_finished` and `Timer::is_paused` to align the public APIs for `Time`, `Timer`, and `Stopwatch`.

Fixes #19110

body:
@FlippinBerger I believe that consistency should win out here - as it helps those who decide not to look at the docs and instead rely on auto-complete (such as intellisense), without causing undue burden on existing users or new users who decide to look at the docs.

Plus, we're already changing the names of certain functions... so I don't quite understand the "prior art" argument.

Yeah I agree with you on the consistency. The prior art argument is that we already have this same pattern being utilized in other crates and I more brought it up to say we either need to leave `just` alone or visit a rename on the input methods as well to keep the full project consistency going. Autocomplete is going to get you there regardless once you type `finished` or `paused` so I think either way the community settles on will be the same end result for usability.

@FlippinBerger For what it's worth, I also think we should rename the input method stuff too, to keep it consistent but descriptive.

Side note: If we want to keep the old names as deprecated aliases for the new names, I wouldn't be opposed.

issue.title: ScriptPipelineState progress quality of life changes
issue.body:
First off, thanks for doing this! Using this has fixed the flakiness I was experiencing with the script not always being ready.

1. When reading the docs for `progress()` it says:

> returns a number between 0 and 100.0 to represent the current script pipeline progress,

But that seems odd to me. A value of `100.0` means "100 percent loaded" but that is a UI concern. If anything, I feel this should return progress as a float between 0.0 and 1.0.

2. `num_loaded_scripts()` should arguably be named `loaded_script_count()` and `num_processing_scripts()` -> `processing_script_count()`. See my argument/rationale from an issue in Bevy: https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/19780#issuecomment-2994554024. It's not an objective choice, but take a look anyway.

3. `processing_batch_completed()` should arguably be named `is_processing_batch_completed()`. You can follow breadcrumbs here https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/19110 but tl;dr; is that most Rust functions seem to use this format.

4. Thinking about `progress()` and my comments in 1., I wonder if you should actually just remove it entirely. Users can already get all the data by calling `num_loaded_scripts()` and `num_processing_scripts()` and I personally wouldn't ever need to know the percent progress: just whether or not it's done. That is, it really feels more like a UI concern. Up to you though!

5. Regarding the use of the term `batch` in `processing_batch_completed()`, what is the purpose? As a user, I don't feel like I really know anything about batches here so it was confusing to me looking at this method name and wondering if it's what I want. If it was just `processing_completed()` (read: `is_processing_completed()`), would that lose any information?
